MySQL by default kills connections if there is no activity on them for eight hours which could cause issues like this. Try passing a `pool_recycle` argument to the `engine_params` segment of the JSON blob in the Datasource setup page. As per the [documentation for SQLAlchemy](http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/core/engines.html#sqlalchemy.create_engine), a value of 3600 for pool_recycle will recycle each connection every hour and should prevent this issue from happening.

you're missing an `END` there
```
sum(CASE WHEN diff=4 THEN 1 ELSE 0 )
->
sum(CASE WHEN diff=4 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END)
```

Looks like there's something else that is wrong in the generated SQL. In previous versions you have to look at the server logs to look at the SQL statement. In recent version you can always get the latest SQL in the UI.

I believe the code here: https://github.com/airbnb/superset/blob/master/superset/utils.py#L418 is supposed to address this, and it does for us. We use the mysqlclient native driver though. I'd recommend trying that.

Should we consider the situation rather than throw a `500 - Internal Server Error`?
```
if db_ds is None or len(db_ds) == 0:
     return None
return db_ds[0]
```
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8108788/23296288/4d237fd2-faaf-11e6-8c17-5f07a6fd4c83.png)

A more pythonic way should be this:
```
if not db_ds:
   return None
```

I have the same issue on Superset 0.15.4 with Firefox and Chrome on Mac. This seems to happen because of some minimum width of the bars, such that sometimes min-width * number of bars > width of slice.  

When refreshing a slice, it shows the whole range for a moment with thinner bars before the final redraw, then finally draws the bars wider, making the chart go outside of the bounds of the slice.  

I've added this custom css to my dashboards as a workaround:
```
div.widget .slice_container {
  overflow: auto;  //was overflow:hidden
}
```
How can we gracefully solve this problem? @mistercrunch

fixed with https://github.com/airbnb/superset/pull/2265

I'm not much of a sys admin but I'd say 1 to 2 gunicorn worker per CPU on each web server box. Mem reqs should be lowish as the web server is stateless, the data is transient and flushed after each web request. From my experience most payloads are fairly small and typically counted KBs or MBs. There's an occasional outlier here and there (large, uncapped CSV exports perhaps), but overall we haven't seen issues on our Superset boxes.

I couldn't find an endpoint on our current version 0.8.? that exposes that metadata...

Also note that at Airbnb we have a framework that loads data in Druid from config files, and that we leverage the metadata defined there to create the Datasources in Superset, meaning that at Airbnb we don't actually use the Superset code to sync datasource metadata anymore.

Say if you want to load some Kafka topic into Druid you fill in a bit of information in a config file (topic, xpath statements to deserialize payload, sample rate, filtering, dims, metrics, ...). Since we have that we use it to create the datasources, which solves the realtime use case. But of course this doesn't work for others...
@mistercrunch for Presto, Redshift and Hive.

We'll have better support for Hive soon on SQL Lab with an estimated progress bar and access to logs.

How's SQL Lab working against Redshift? There's a bit of confusion around schema/database/owner hierarchy in SQLAlchemy that results in uneven features and bugs on our side I think.
Oh I see you have that PR open, I'll take a look.

The long term solution should live in `db_engine_specs.py` with a bool class attribute `has_schemas` and a `get_schemas` method. Somehow this would have to make it to the frontend and translate into an extra dropdown on the left panel. 

This is a fairly significant change so I'm ok enabling this in the meantime to get Redshift/Postgres on track.
@mistercrunch glad to hear good news in terms of Hive, there's a bunch of bugs/minor issues than Hue as you know.

What got labeled 0.16.0 on master wasn't fully baked for a Pypi release though it did hit our production with some casualties. I'm kind of glad we did not release it to Pypi. Next release should be soon as things stabilizes in our production.

We should make it such that `superset refresh_druid` creates perms where needed. I'll hickjack this issue by renaming it.

Related, from the Druid docs here http://druid.io/docs/latest/querying/topnquery.html:

TopNs are approximate in that each node will rank their top K results and only return those top K results to the broker. K, by default in Druid, is max(1000, threshold). In practice, this means that if you ask for the top 1000 items ordered, the correctness of the first ~900 items will be 100%, and the ordering of the results after that is not guaranteed. TopNs can be made more accurate by increasing the threshold.
